awd_titl_txt: Galactic Novae: Thinking Inside the Envelope
awd_abstract_narration:
1.	A nova is a star that brightens abruptly by a large factor.  Some novae may become as much as tens of thousands of times brighter than our Sun.  The rapid brightening is caused by a runaway thermonuclear explosion on the surface of a white dwarf star; a small star that packs about as much mass as our Sun into a volume the size of Earth.  The white dwarf accumulates the hydrogen that fuels the nova outburst from an ordinary star that is a close companion.  The explosion ejects mass from the surface of the white dwarf, enriching space with heavier elements produced during the thermonuclear explosion.  Although novae have been known since ancient times, and astrophysicists have understood the cause of a nova explosion since the middle of the last century, important puzzles still remain.  Over the past several years, spacecraft observations have revealed that at least some novae emit very high-energy gamma radiation.  This was unexpected and is still mysterious.  Some novae also may be progenitors of Type Ia supernovae, which have significant implications for cosmology.  The Principal Investigator will conduct extensive scientific analyses of the atlas of observational data he has accumulated for 83 novae over the past 14 years.  This research will address several key questions about novae.  The results of the investigations constitute the Intellectual Merit of this project.  The Broader Impacts stem from the PI's proposed involvement of undergraduates and high-school students directly in the research.  He points out that since 1991, five of the high-school students he has supervised have been semi-finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search.  The PI will also collaborate with the American Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO) to enhance the experiences of participating amateur observers.

2.	Nova eruptions are caused by thermonuclear runaways at the degenerate base of an accreted H layer on a white dwarf.  The hydrogen layer is accumulated by mass transfer from a close binary companion star.  During outburst, a nova increases in brightness, in some cases reaching tens of thousands of times the luminosity of the Sun.  A nova explosion ejects as much one ten-thousandth of a solar mass from the white dwarf into the interstellar medium, enriching it in heavier elements produced in the nuclear burning event.  During the past several years, the Fermi Gamma Ray Observatory has discovered that some novae emit high-energy gamma radiation; the origin of these emissions is still not well understood.  Some novae also may be the precursors of Type Ia supernovae, which have important implications for cosmology.  In order to address several key questions about these eruptive variables, the Principal Investigator will conduct exhaustive scientific analyses of the atlas of high-cadence photometric and spectroscopic data he has accumulated for 83 novae over the past 14 years.  The results of these investigations constitute the Intellectual Merit of this project.  The Broader Impacts stem from the PI's proposed involvement of undergraduates and high-school students directly in the research.  He points out that since 1991, five of the high-school students he has supervised have been semi-finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search.  The PI will also collaborate with the American Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO) to enhance the experiences of participating amateur observers.

por.por_cntn:
Novae are manifestations of thermonuclear runaways (essentially hydrogen bombs) occurring on the surfaces of white dwarf stars accreting from a companion star in a close binary star system. They are of interest because studies of novae further our understanding of such diverse phenomena as mass  accretion, the physics of the thermonuclear runaway, dust formation,  and the evolution of binary systems. They are of interest because recent observations have shown that galactic novae are transient sources of 100 MeV gamma rays, and are also a source of Lithium in our Galaxy (the Galactic Li abundance is nearly a factor of 10 higher than the cosmological abundance). Novae also have cosmological implications, because if they gain mass over the nova cycle (novae repeat, as the explosion does not disrupt the binary system) then they may be a progenitor of Type Ia supernovae, one of our cosmological "standard candles".

This grant funded the continuation of an observational study of galactic novae that we begain in 2003. This grant supported acquisition and analysis of high cadence photometry and spectroscopy of about 100 novae. Most of the data were obtained at the SMARTS facilities at the Cerro Tololo InterAmerican Observatory (CTIO), the photometry on the Andicam dual-channel photometer and the spectroscopy with the Chiron bench-mounted spectrograph. The data are available through the Stony Brook/SMARTS Atlas of (mostly) Southern Novae web page, hosted by Stony Brook University.

Photometry consists of measuring the brightness of an objects at various wavelengths. Andicam permitted simultaneous optical and near-infrared observations. This provides a broad look at the physical conditions, the rate of decay of the novae, and the formation of dust. Unique to most investigations, dust is normally seen only in absorption in the optical, but Andicam let us see dust in emission in the near-infrared. The fraction of novae that form dust on the line of sight is about 20%; we now known that the fraction of classical novae that form dust is about 80%, showing that dust does not form in a spherical shell.

High dispersion spectroscopy lets us study the motions of the ejected gas, as well as the physical conditions revealed by individual emission lines. Images formed by stacking nightly spectra reveal the appearance of multiple absorption systems due to gas ejected at low velocities in slow novae prior to the formartion of dust. These novae tend to stay about the same brightness for a few months before beginning to fade; the absorption systems tend to appear as the nova brightness briefly fades prior to recovering. These episodic ejections, at velocities of a few hundred km/s and involving far less mass than the original mass ejection, may be driven by ionization instabilities in the envelope.

The photometry and spectroscopy have shown that a few novae have maintained a high mass accretion rate for over a decade, revealed either by a bright blue conrtinuum from an accretion disk or hot permitted lines with temperatures over half a million K. In either case the data suggest mass accretion rates that suggest that the white dwarf will gain mass throught its nova cycle, eventually approaching the Chandrasekhar mass, at which point it may explode as a Type Ia supernova.

The NSF support has allowed us to involve 3 graduate students and 6 undergraduate students in research. We have also benefitted from a close cooperation with amateur observers at the American Association of Variable Star Observers. Data have been disseminated in a number of professional publications and meetings; outreach has consisted of a number of presentations to the general public.

With nearly 20 years of data on some novae, and intensive high cadence, years-long observing sequences on some recent bright novae, we have barely begun to understand everything we have. With NSF support we have gathered a unique observational dataset; the analysis will continue for years to come.
